THE COLSTRIP WATER TREATMENT PLANT
                                                      EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
                                                   RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
 

REASONS FOR 

Section 112. of the Federal Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990 was published by EPA on June 20, 1996. This rule is otherwise known as the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) (40 CFR part 68). The rule requires that each affected business develop and implement a Risk Management Program. The goal of the RMP is to prevent accidental releases of toxic or flammable substances that can cause serious harm to the public health and the environment and to mitigate the effects of releases that do occur. It will ensure that responders and the citizens of Colstrip are aware of any hazards associated with an emergency at the Colstrip Water Treatment Plant.

THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONCE POLICY

  IN AUGUST 1998,  A PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PLAN WAS WRITTEN AND ADOPTED. 
 7 The purpose is to establish normal procedures for handling hazardous chemicals that are regulated by the Occupation Safety and Health Administration.  This procedure has been written for compliance to 29 CFR 1910.119.
7 This procedure identifies what requirements are necessary for the continuous use of chlorine gas as an oxidizing biocide at the Colstrip Water and Wastewater Treatment Plants. 
 7 This procedure applies to all employees that work at the Colstrip Community Services Company who operate or support the operation of the Water and Wastewater Plants.
 7 A Copy of the PSMP is kept on file at the Water Treatment Plant and at the Colstrip Community Services office.

OUR FACILITY AND THE SUBSTANCES HANDLED

  THE COLSTRIP WATER TREATMENT PLANT IS LOCATED NORTHWEST OF THE TOWN OF COLSTRIP AT  45 53.39N AND -106 38.02W,  JUST EAST OF CASTLE ROCK LAKE. 
 7 The Colstrip Water Treatment Plant is operated by Colstrip Community Services and  e

mploys state certified water and wastewater operators to install, operate, maintain, and comply with environmental regulations.
 7 Review of existing processes at the Colstrip Water Treatment Plant has identified chlorine as the only chemical that is regulated. There is a maximum inventory of 4000 lbs of chlorine onsite. The chlorine is liquefied under pressure and is packaged in the form of two 1 ton cylinders. Chlorine is dangerous as a gas or liquid. Chlorine gas is used in the treatment process as a disinfectant killing greater than 99.99% of all waterborne pathogens. It is also used in the optimization of the filtering process.
 7 Chlorine gas irritates the respiratory system, mucous membranes, eyes, and skin.  Breathing air containing high concentrations of chlorine can result in death.  The OSHA permissible exposure limit (PEL) and the threshold limit value (TLV) are 0.5 ppm. The EPA toxic endpoint is based on 3 ppm. Liquid chlorine can cause skin and eye burns upon contact.  When open to the air, liquid chlorine vaporizes to chlorine gas expanding 460 times when changing from the liquid state to the gaseous state. 
 7 The hazards of exposure to chlorine can be mitigated by proper handling.  Essentially proper handling of chlorine means using operating and maintenance practices which will keep it confined in shipping containers, storage tanks and plant piping.  Chlorine can be dangerous when it escapes to the atmosphere.  Chlorine has a pungent odor and is detectable at very low concentrations (approximately 1 ppm) and initially alerts workers of a potentially dangerous situation.  Employees must be aware that with time people lose their ability to smell chlorine because it numbs the olfactory nerves.  Chlorine gas is heavier than air so the gas will stay close to the ground when dispersed by the wind and it will accumulate in low places.
 7 Employees whose work includes the operation or maintenance of chlorination equipment must have adequate knowledge of

its chemical hazards and be properly trained. 
 
 
THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS

 THE WORST CASE SCENARIO IS BASED ON THE EPA'S RMP*COMP MODEL.
7 Involves a vessel leak from a 1 ton cylinder. A release of 2000 lbs of chlorine at 200 lbs/min for 10 minutes with a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec. The distance to the toxic endpoint is a 1 mile radius from the Water Treatment Plant. 
7 The effected area is approximately 2.4 square miles and encompasses more than half of Colstrip. Anyone inside this area would need to be evacuated. The area includes everything from just south of Willow Avenue to the power plants on the east to Chisholm street on the north. The industrial park is included as well as is all of the Cimerron area. The estimated population within this area is 1500 people and includes Isabel Bills Elementary School and the Frank Brattin Middle School. The Colstrip High School and Pine Butte Elementary schools are on the outer perimeter but might want to be included in an evacuation as a precautionary measure.
 
 THE ALTERNATE SCENARIO IS BASED ON THE EPA'S RMP*COMP MODEL
7 Involves a vessel leak from a 1 ton cylinder. A release of 450 lbs of chlorine at 7 lbs/min for 60 minutes with a wind speed of 3 m/sec. The distance to the toxic endpoint is a .1 mile radius from the Water Treatment Plant.
7 Since the effected area is only a tenth of a mile a release of this nature would not reach State Highway 39 or any residential areas. There arent any people within this area except perhaps Water Treatment personnel and perhaps personnel at the MPC pump house. Recreational users of Castle Rock Lake around the dam area, although outside this perimeter, may also need to be warned of the hazard.
 

THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

 THE KEY TO PREVENTING ACCIDENTS IS HAVING A GOOD PREVENTION PROGRAM
7 The Colstrip Water Treatment Plant complies with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations including the OSHA PSM rule.

situation and coordinating response activities.  The IC will decide when an evacuation is necessary, and will also determine when an emergency is over. The On-Call-Person shall act as the IC unless another person is or has been designated.
 7 Safety Officer - The IC must appoint someone to act as Safety Officer before any response activities may begin, as required by 29 CFR 1910.120.  This Safety Officer is responsible for identifying and evaluating hazards, and for providing direction for the safety of operations.  Other than the IC, the Safety Officer is the only person who has the authority to stop all activities at an incident due to unsafe conditions.
 7 Necessary Personnel - These personnel are designated by the On-Call-Person.

RESPONSIBILITIES
7 All Colstrip Project Division Employees  - All employees are responsible for reporting any emergency situation that they may witness or encounter in accordance with CPD Procedure 7.1 -Emergency Response Telephone Number 311.  Any employee may declare that an emergency situation has occurred and put Procedure 7.1 into effect by dialing 311 on any telephone.  Personnel do not need to contact a supervisor before they report the emergency situation.
  7 Security Personnel
 7 All 311 calls are received at the Security office in accordance with Procedure 7.1 Security shall notify the On-Call-Person of the emergency.
 7 Security shall be responsible for call-out of Safety/Training Department personnel, Environmental Department personnel, the CPD Emergency Medical Response Team, or outside agencies as requested by the IC.
7 If the IC decides that a town site evacuation is necessary, Security shall call the local authorities
7 On-Call-Person - It shall be the responsibility of the On-Call-Person when notified of an emergency situation, to immediately appoint himself or another qualified person to act as the Incident Commander for the incident.
 7 Incident Commander (IC On-Call-Person) 
 7 The IC shall appoint a Safety Offi

ment Plant personnel follow all manufactures guidelines when  operating and maintaining the chlorinating equipment.
7 All chlorine handling procedures are followed as set down by the Chlorine Institute and an Emergency Kit B is maintained onsite for emergency repair of the one ton containers.
7 It is required that all venders are OSHA compliant and that all delivery personnel use safe handling practices.
7 A chlorine leak detector is used and is connected to an alarm system. The alarm system alerts Montana Power security personnel to any problems within minutes of any leak
7 The chlorine containers are tested and certified by the chlorine venders on a regular basis.
 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

 THERE HAVE BEEN NO REPORTABLE ACCIDENTS IN THE LAST 5 YEARS


THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

PURPOSE:
7 This procedure establishes the procedures for conducting an emergency response at the Colstrip Community Services Company (CCSC) Water Treatment Plant.
 
SCOPE:
7 This procedure identifies the responsibilities and requirements for an event that requires an emergency response or evacuation at CCSC facilities.

APPLICABILITY:
7 This procedure shall apply to the Colstrip Water Treatment Plant.
 
DEFINITIONS:
7 Emergency Telephones - Telephones have been installed in the lab of the facility designated for reporting emergencies
 7 Emergency Situation - Any situation that requires immediate attention and/or immediate assistance from internal or external emergency response personnel.  Examples include fires, accidents, sudden serious illness, explosions, extreme weather events, chemical release requiring emergency assistance, etc.
 7 Evacuation - Any emergency situation in which personnel are removed from an area.  An evacuation may be done in the specific area that contains the hazard, or it could be done in an area as extensive as the entire town site.
 7 Incident Commander (IC On Call Person) - This is the individual who assumes responsibility for controlling an emergency

cer.
 7 The IC shall initiate and coordinate any required actions based upon available information and his/her own investigation. If Security has not already requested agency assistance, the IC may do so by requesting Security to make the calls.
 7 The IC shall determine whether an emergency situation requires an evacuation.  If an evacuation is required, the IC shall decide whether the entire facility must be evacuated or just the section(s) of the facility where the hazard exists.
 7 The IC shall interface with, and coordinate activities with outside entities such as the Fire Department.
 7 The IC shall determine when the emergency situation is over and the hazard no longer exists.
 7 Public information release shall only be given under the direction of the IC and/or the Corporate Communications Department.
 7 The IC shall forward information concerning the emergency situation to the Safety/Training Department within 24 hours.  The Environmental Department shall also get a copy if there was an environmental emergency.
  7 Safety/Training Department
  7 The Safety/Training Department shall assist the IC as requested, and shall conduct the post-evacuation critique.
 7 The Safety/Training Department shall provide 
 7 annual training on the Evacuation Procedure to all employees.
 7 The Safety/Training Department shall provide any special training that is required for the Incident Commanders, Safety Officers, and required personnel.
 7 The Safety/Training Department shall initiate an evacuation drill at least once each year.  It shall be announced that this is only a drill.  The results of the drill will be used to train employees and to improve this procedure.
    7 Environmental Department
 7 The Environmental Department personnel shall assist the IC as requested
 7 The Environmental Department shall coordinate any necessary activities associated with environmental cleanup, environmental regulatory liaison, etc.
7 The Environmental Department shall assist with the po

st-evacuation critique.
       REQUIREMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
7 When CPD personnel discover or witness an emergency situation, they shall immediately, without delay, report the situation by the most direct means at their disposal.  This shall be done by dialing extension 311 from any on site telephone, or by using the company radios.
 7 Unless other arrangements are made, the On-Call-Person shall act as the IC for the emergency situation.
 7 Additional instructions from the IC will be given over the radio, and/or personally.
 7 No one shall re-enter the facility until authorization has been given by the IC.  When the emergency situation is over and the hazard no longer exists, the all clear shall be announced on the radios.
 7 Any situation requiring an evacuation shall be followed by a post-evacuation critique as soon after the emergency as possible.  During this critique, reports from all groups involved in the emergency shall be gathered and evaluated.  This information shall be use to improve the Evacuation Procedure.
 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

 PERIODIC REPLACEMENT OF CHLORINATION EQUIPMENT HELPS REDUCE THE CHANCE OF EQUIPMENT FAILURE DUE TO AGE AND FATIGUE. 
7 Replacement of the chlorine leak detector is planned. It is close to twenty years old and has become unreliable.
 7 Modifications to the heating system in the chlorine room are being planned to help eliminate the possibility of fusible plug meltdown due to overheating. It will also prevent the breakage of waterlines from freezing as has happened in the past.
 7 A windsock is being added onsite which will aid in the determination of the direction of chlorine drift in the event of a leak.
 7 The 1 ton cylinder repair kit is being modified and all old rubber parts are being replaced.
